results.title: In First Interview From Jail, an Upbeat Navalny Discusses Prison Life
results.abstract: Russian political prisoners today are subjected to “psychological” pressure, said the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who is forced to watch state TV for more than eight hours a day.

multimedia.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny in May. “Imagine something like a Chinese labor camp,” he said of his prison experience, adding, “There is constant control and a culture of snitching.”
multimedia.copyright: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

multimedia.caption: Aleksei A. Navalny in May. “Imagine something like a Chinese labor camp,” he said of his prison experience, adding, “There is constant control and a culture of snitching.”

results.title: Rejecting Covid Inquiry, China Peddles Conspiracy Theories Blaming the U.S.
results.abstract: A new wave of disinformation follows President Biden’s order for the United States to investigate the origin of the pandemic, including the possibility of a lab leak in Wuhan.
results.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Amy Chang Chien

multimedia.caption: A lab at Fort Detrick in Maryland. Beijing is peddling groundless theories that the United States is the source of the coronavirus.

results.title: How Mexico Helped The Times Get Its Journalists Out of Afghanistan
results.abstract: A humanitarian effort led by Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard gave Afghans and their families a sanctuary amid the fast-unfolding crisis.

results.title: Budding Resistance to the Taliban Faces Long Odds

results.title: How Many People in Afghanistan Need to be Rescued? The Number Remains Elusive.

results.title: Biden Sticks to Afghan Deadline, Resisting Pleas to Extend Evacuation
results.abstract: The American withdrawal coincided with a threat by the Taliban to stop Afghans from traveling to the airport, an ominous sign that the window may be slamming shut for thousands of people desperate to leave.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Under Taliban Rule, Life in Kabul Transforms Once Again

results.title: Chinese Citizen Who Documented Wuhan Outbreak Falls Ill in Prison Hunger Strike
results.abstract: Zhang Zhan was sentenced to four years for videos about failures in handling the virus. She now weighs less than 90 pounds, her former lawyer says.
results.byline: By Amy Chang Chien and Austin Ramzy
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: Zhang Zhan in Wuhan, China, last year. She declined to appeal her conviction, telling her lawyers that she refused to acknowledge the validity of the legal process used to imprison her.

results.title: Few Women Ascend Japan’s Corporate Ladder. Is Change Finally Coming?
results.abstract: Only 6 percent of board seats at Japanese companies are held by women. After years of unkept promises, these businesses are now facing pressure both at home and abroad to diversify.

multimedia.caption: Naomi Koshi, a lawyer who serves on two corporate boards, said she first understood the inequality in Japan in 2000, when she graduated from college.
multimedia.copyright: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

results.title: Montenegro Pledges to Stamp Out a Deadly Trade: Cigarette Smuggling

results.title: Why Representatives Seth Moulton and Peter Meijer Secretly Traveled to Kabul
results.abstract: They said they could not get answers on the evacuation from the Biden administration, so they went to Afghanistan to see for themselves. The visit earned bipartisan rebukes.

results.title: Chicago will require city workers to be vaccinated, the mayor says.

results.title: ISIS Branch Poses Biggest Immediate Terror Threat to Evacuation in Kabul
results.abstract: An Islamic State affiliate that is a sworn enemy of both the Taliban and the United States threatens a large-scale attack against the mission at the airport.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Outside the international airport in Kabul on Wednesday. The biggest immediate threat to the Americans and the Taliban as the United States escalates its evacuation is ISIS-K, the Islamic State’s affiliate in Afghanistan.

results.title: Two House members secretly flew to Kabul on an unauthorized oversight mission.
results.abstract: Biden administration officials said the trip by Representatives Seth Moulton and Peter Meijer had wasted resources needed to help evacuate people in Afghanistan.

results.title: Military Ramps Up Evacuations From Kabul, but Bottlenecks Persist
results.abstract: The Pentagon has increased the number of flights, but questions remain about whether the military can sustain the pace as the deadline to end the operation draws near.
results.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
